slides.title: Managing contacts
slides.ocrText: Managing contacts

slides.title: Learning Objectives
slides.ocrText:
Lesson
objectives

Create a contact in ClaimCenter

Assign or reassign roles to contacts on a claim
Add a vendor contact to a claim

Describe how ClaimCenter and
ContactManager share contacts

slides.title: Review: Parts of a claim (1 of)
slides.originalNotes:
Review: Parts of a claim (I of 9)
A claim is an event in which one or more potential covered losses occurred. A claim consists of multiple mostly related parts.
slides.notes:
Review: Parts of a claim (I of 9)
A claim is an event in which one or more potential covered losses occurred. A claim consists of multiple mostly related parts.
slides.ocrText: | Review: Parts of a claim (1 of) Gi

slides.title: Review: Parts of a claim (2 of 9)
slides.originalNotes:
Review: Parts of a claim (2 of 9)
A contact is a person or organization who has a relationship to a claim. A contact may be a claimant requesting compensation for a loss, the reporter of the claim, a doctor treating an injury that resulted from the occurrence, a vendor providing services to claimants and more. Each of these contacts has a unique role or relationship to the claim.
slides.notes:
Review: Parts of a claim (2 of 9)
A contact is a person or organization who has a relationship to a claim. A contact may be a claimant requesting compensation for a loss, the reporter of the claim, a doctor treating an injury that resulted from the occurrence, a vendor providing services to claimants and more. Each of these contacts has a unique role or relationship to the claim.

slides.title: Review: Parts of a claim (3 of 9)
slides.originalNotes:
Review: Parts of a claim (3 of 9)
An incident is an item that was lost or damaged, such as a vehicle, property, or a person suffering one or more injuries.

A service request is a mechanism to track vendor progress, receive quotes from vendors, and provide a list of services available and vendors that provide those services.
slides.notes:

A service request is a mechanism to track vendor progress, receive quotes from vendors, and provide a list of services available and vendors that provide those services.

slides.title: Review: Parts of a claim (4 of9)
slides.originalNotes:
Review: Parts of a claim (4 of 9)
An exposure is a set of data used to track a potential payment from one coverage to one claimant. A reserve line is an amount of money set aside for expected payments related to a given exposure. A check is a single transfer of money tracked by an exposure to one or more individuals or organizations. The transfer of money may be a traditional check or an Electronic Funds Transfer, or EFT.

slides.title: Discussion
slides.ocrText:
| Discussion

As a claims adjuster, | need to keep track of
everyone who is associated with a claim. That could
mean witnesses, pedestrians, claimants or even
vendors who have some relationship with the claim.
How does ClaimCenter keep track of involved
parties? Does ClaimCenter integrate with another
system to manage contacts?

_Tanvi
Adjuster \s9/

slides.title: What is a contact?
slides.originalNotes:
What is a contact?
All parties that have a relationship to a claim are contacts. Contacts may be a person, an organization, a vendor, or even a venue such a court. Each of those types of contacts will have some type of relationship to the claim. Forexample, a person may be the claimant, a reporter, a witness and so on.
slides.notes:
What is a contact?
All parties that have a relationship to a claim are contacts. Contacts may be a person, an organization, a vendor, or even a venue such a court. Each of those types of contacts will have some type of relationship to the claim. Forexample, a person may be the claimant, a reporter, a witness and so on.
slides.ocrText:
| What is a contact? G

UW L )
claimant reporter auto repair shop hospital doctor court

Acontact is a person, organization, vendor, or venue which is related to the claim,
such as...

* Someone who suffered a loss

*« Acompany or vendor which repaired a damaged asset or treated an injured person

« A place where disputes were resolved

slides.title: Two applications store contacts
slides.originalNotes:
Two applications store contacts
Most insurers with claims processing systems have a contact management application, which is often referred to in the industry as Address Book.

ClaimCenter comes with a separate Address Book application called Contact Manager. ClaimCenter and Contact Manager are integrated, and most of the functionality belonging to Contact Manager appears seamlessly in ClaimCenter.

ClaimCenter stores contact information that is related to a single claim within ClaimCenter. Contact Manager stores contact information for vendors or other parties that are relevant to multiple claims. For example, an auto repair shop, a Doctor or Lawyer, or even a venue such as a courthouse, are all examples of multi-use contacts that would be stored and maintained in Contact Manager. Contacts can be shared across both applications.
slides.notes:
Two applications store contacts
Most insurers with claims processing systems have a contact management application, which is often referred to in the industry as Address Book.

ClaimCenter comes with a separate Address Book application called Contact Manager. ClaimCenter and Contact Manager are integrated, and most of the functionality belonging to Contact Manager appears seamlessly in ClaimCenter.

ClaimCenter stores contact information that is related to a single claim within ClaimCenter. Contact Manager stores contact information for vendors or other parties that are relevant to multiple claims. For example, an auto repair shop, a Doctor or Lawyer, or even a venue such as a courthouse, are all examples of multi-use contacts that would be stored and maintained in Contact Manager. Contacts can be shared across both applications.
slides.ocrText:
| Two applications store contacts

ClaimCenter ContactManager

(Address Book)

contacts

relevant to

multiple claims
—

Two applications store contacts
* ClaimCenter stores contact information as it pertains to a claim (single use)
* ContactManager stores contacts that are relevant to multiple claims (multi-use)
* Contacts can be shared across both applications

slides.title: Local contacts
slides.originalNotes:
Local contacts
Most ClaimCenter contacts exist only in ClaimCenter, and not in Contact Manager. This is the case when a claim related contact is not expected to be used for any other claim, which is typically true of any persons related to the claim. For example, the claimant, witnesses, passengers, and so on will have a relationship only to a specific claim- There is no need for their contact information to be shared across multiple claims, so the contact is not stored in Contact Manager. This is also known as a local contact, which is local for ClaimCenter.
slides.notes:
Local contacts
Most ClaimCenter contacts exist only in ClaimCenter, and not in Contact Manager. This is the case when a claim related contact is not expected to be used for any other claim, which is typically true of any persons related to the claim. For example, the claimant, witnesses, passengers, and so on will have a relationship only to a specific claim- There is no need for their contact information to be shared across multiple claims, so the contact is not stored in Contact Manager. This is also known as a local contact, which is local for ClaimCenter.

slides.title: Shared contacts
slides.originalNotes:
Shared contacts
Some ClaimCenter contacts may also exist in Contact Manager- A contact exists in Contact Manager when the contact is used or is expected to be used for multiple claims. This is typically true for person vendors such as doctors and lawyers, company vendors such as hospitals, or venues such as courts. Because there is a need for contact information to be shared across multiple claims, the contact is stored in Contact Manager. When the contact is used on a claim, ClaimCenter keeps a local copy of any of those shared contacts. In this example, Contact Manager has one copy of Dr- Sawyer, while ClaimCenter has 3 copies, one for each claim that has a relationship with the Doctor.
slides.notes:
Shared contacts

This is typically true for person vendors such as doctors and lawyers, company vendors such as hospitals, or venues such as courts. When the contact is used on a claim, ClaimCenter keeps a local copy of any of those shared contacts. In this example, Contact Manager has one copy of Dr- Sawyer, while ClaimCenter has 3 copies, one for each claim that has a relationship with the Doctor.

slides.title: Adding contacts to a claim (1 of 5)
slides.originalNotes:
Adding contacts to a claim (I of 5)
Within ClaimCenter, contacts only exist when related to a claim with some role on that claim, like a passenger, injured party, a vendor, and so on. Because this mandatory relationship for a contact, you can only create a contact from a claim, and notindependent of a claim in.
slides.notes:
Adding contacts to a claim (I of 5)

slides.title: Adding contacts to a claim (2 of 5)
slides.originalNotes:
Adding contacts to a claim (2 of 5)
There are two approaches for adding a contact to a claim. First, you can add a non-vendor contact to a claim in several screens including the Parties Involved screen.

In this case, the contact is a local contact who exists only in ClaimCenter and for the current claim. The minimal information for a contact must be provided at the time you add the contact to the claim. Generally, that includes a name and the role that the contact has on the claim.
slides.notes:
Adding contacts to a claim (2 of 5)
There are two approaches for adding a contact to a claim. First, you can add a non-vendor contact to a claim in several screens including the Parties Involved screen.

In this case, the contact is a local contact who exists only in ClaimCenter and for the current claim. The minimal information for a contact must be provided at the time you add the contact to the claim. Generally, that includes a name and the role that the contact has on the claim.

slides.title: Adding contacts to a claim (5 of 5)
slides.originalNotes:
Adding contacts to a claim (5 of 5)
When adding an existing contact, a new object is created in ClaimCenter, but the information for that object is copied from Contact Manager.

The objects are automatically linked.

slides.title: New contacts in ClaimCenter
slides.originalNotes:
New contacts in ClaimCenter
When you add a contact within ClaimCenter, it will always be in the context of a claim. You cannot add a contact which is stand- alone or not within a claim. Since every contact is related to claim, you must specify what that relationship is. In other words, you must specify a role for the contact. Contacts may be related to the overall claim, a specific exposure, an incident, or even the policy. For example, the role of reporter is typically the policyholder, or the insured, and is related to the claim. An injured party will probably have a role related to a specific incident on a claim.

Any contact you create in ClaimCenter may be linked to Contact Manager, however Persons or Companies are typically not linked. Vendors, which are used across multiple claims are typically shared from Contact Manager. While creating a contact in ClaimCenter, the Check for Duplicates button looks at Contact Manager to see if there is a possible match to an existing contact. Again, this is primarily used for vendors.
slides.notes:

For example, the role of reporter is typically the policyholder, or the insured, and is related to the claim. An injured party will probably have a role related to a specific incident on a claim.

Vendors, which are used across multiple claims are typically shared from Contact Manager. slides.title: Creating contacts in NCW
slides.originalNotes:
Creating contacts in NCW
During the New Claim wizard, you can add contacts to a claim at multiple points, including the Basic information step, the Add Claim information step, and the Parties Involved screen. In the Basic Information step, a contact has a pre-defined role. For example, the contact specified in the Reported By section has the role reporter. If the user adds a contact in the Main Contact section that contact will have the role main contact.

In other places, such as the Parties Involved step, a contact can have any role. For example,a contact added here could be a witness, an alternate contact, an attorney and so on.

You may also create contacts in the New Claim Wizard when adding service requests to a Claim
slides.notes:
Creating contacts in NCW
During the New Claim wizard, you can add contacts to a claim at multiple points, including the Basic information step, the Add Claim information step, and the Parties Involved screen. In the Basic Information step, a contact has a pre-defined role. For example, the contact specified in the Reported By section has the role reporter. If the user adds a contact in the Main Contact section that contact will have the role main contact.

In other places, such as the Parties Involved step, a contact can have any role. For example,a contact added here could be a witness, an alternate contact, an attorney and so on.

You may also create contacts in the New Claim Wizard when adding service requests to a Claim

slides.title: Contact roles
slides.originalNotes:
Contact roles
When a contact is associated with a claim, it must have one or more roles on the claim. The role identifies the relationship between the contact and the claim. Each role can be related to the claim or one of its parts. This relationship designates that the contact has this role for the entire claim, for the policy, for a specific exposure, for a service, or for a specific incident.

In the example, Ellen has 3 roles on the auto claim: she is the insured on the policy, the reporter of the claim, and aclaimant on an exposure- Jim has the role of witness for the entire claim.
Matt Sawyer has the role of Doctor for the exposure- Notice that Matt also has the role of Doctor for an exposure on the Workers' Comp claim.

There are two unique objects corresponding to Matt Sawyer. In this case, Matt is a Vendor Doctor maintained in Contact Manager. When he was added to these two claims, two unique objects were created in ClaimCenter- Fields within one object may have the same values or different values than the corresponding fields in the other object. For example, Matt Sawyers address may be the same in both contact objects, but the okay to contact field may be different- It could be okay to contact him for the workers' comp claim but not okay to contact him for the auto claim.

Note that the 'insured" on the WC (Workers' Comp) claim is a business , Tech Supplies Inc.. Workers' Comp insurance is commercial insurance, meaning the policyholder is an employer that is often (depending on the law) required to hold a WC policy. The policy is to indemnify workers for lost wages and/or medical bills resulting from injuries sustained during the course of employment. This is different than personal auto insurance, in which the insured is an individual.

Note that the 'insured" on the WC (Workers' Comp) claim is a business , Tech Supplies Inc.. Workers' Comp insurance is commercial insurance, meaning the policyholder is an employer that is often (depending on the law) required to hold a WC policy. The policy is to indemnify workers for lost wages and/or medical bills resulting from injuries sustained during the course of employment. This is different than personal auto insurance, in which the insured is an individual.

slides.title: Adding a vendor contact to a claim
slides.originalNotes:
Adding a vendor contact to a claim
Contact Manager, or Address Book, stores and maintains contacts that have relationships to multiple claims. These contacts are vendors in various forms. They can be company vendors, person vendors, or even a place like a courthouse.

To add an existing vendor, contact to a claim the user clicks Add Existing Contact. That starts a search that searches Contact Manager. The user can specify the type of vendor, like company, person, place and so on, and then provides the name or location of the vendor. Contact Manager returns a list of vendors that match the criteria. The user selects the vendor and assigns a role.

The vendor is then copied to ClaimCenter and automatically linked to Contact Manager.
slides.notes:
Adding a vendor contact to a claim
Contact Manager, or Address Book, stores and maintains contacts that have relationships to multiple claims. These contacts are vendors in various forms. They can be company vendors, person vendors, or even a place like a courthouse.

To add an existing vendor, contact to a claim the user clicks Add Existing Contact. That starts a search that searches Contact Manager. The user can specify the type of vendor, like company, person, place and so on, and then provides the name or location of the vendor. Contact Manager returns a list of vendors that match the criteria. The user selects the vendor and assigns a role.

The vendor is then copied to ClaimCenter and automatically linked to Contact Manager.

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
|f “Tire Town” is in Address Book and is associated with three claims,
how many contacts have the name “Tire Town"?
•
SSoopooD OOOO OD ooo
Gi

questionData.question: If “Tire Town” is in Address Book and is associated with three claims, how many contacts have the name “Tire Town"?
questionData.answer: Four. There would be one contact in ContactManager and three in ClaimCenter. Every contact, whether it is linked or not, is a unique and separate object.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
'sitcommon or uncommon to have a contact that exists only in
• ClaimCenter? Only in ContactManager?
•
•
SSoopooD OOOO OD ooo

questionData.question:
Is it common or uncommon to have a contact that exists only in
ClaimCenter? Only in ContactManager?
questionData.answer: It is common to have a contact that exists only in ClaimCenter. This is true for contacts that are relevant to only one claim (such as a witness or passenger). It is uncommon to have a contact exist only in Address Book. The primary purpose for a contact in Address Book is to have it associated with multiple claims, and if it is associated with even one claim, then the contact will also exist in ClaimCenter.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer [a
'sitcommon or uncommon to have a contact that exists only in
• ClaimCenter? Only in ContactManager?
•
•
It is common to have a contact that exists only in ClaimCenter. This is true for contacts
that are relevant to only one claim (such as a witness or passenger). It is uncommon
to have a contact exist only in Address Book. The primary purpose for a contact in
Address Book is to have it associated with multiple claims, and if it is associated with
even one claim, then the contact will also exist in ClaimCenter.
SS Oooo D OOOO ODD oo

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
What is the purpose of a contact role?
•
•
SSoopooD OOOO OD ooo

questionData.question: What is the purpose of a contact role?
questionData.answer: A contact role identifies the relationship that the contact has with the claim (such as insured, witness, doctor, and so on).

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer
What is the purpose of a contact role?
•
•
Acontact role identifies the relationship that the contact has with the claim (such as
insured, witness, doctor, and so on).

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
Howcan you tell if a contact is linked or in sync?
•
•
SSoopooD OOOO OD ooo

questionData.question: How can you tell if a contact is linked or in sync?
questionData.answer: You can tell whether a contact is linked and/or in sync by selecting the contact from the Parties Involved — Contacts’ screen. A label on the Basics card identifies the contact's status.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer
Howcan you tell if a contact is linked or in sync?
•
•
You can tell whether a contact is linked and/or in sync by selecting the contact from
the Parties Involved — Contacts’ screen. A label on the Basics card identifies the
contact's status.
SS Oooo D OOOO ODD oo

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
How many claims can a contact be associated with if the contact is only
defined in ClaimCenter?
SSoopooD OOOO OD ooo
Gi

questionData.question: How many claims can a contact be associated with if the contact is only defined in ClaimCenter?
questionData.answer: One. Each contact is created within a claim. If a contact (usually an insured) has multiple claims, there will be a separate contact on each of those claims.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer
How many claims can a contact be associated with if the contact is only
defined in ClaimCenter?
One. Each contact is created within a claim. If a contact (usually an insured) has
multiple claims, there will be a separate contact on each of those claims.
SS Oooo D OOOO ODD oo
Gi

slides.title: Key Takeaways
slides.ocrText:
Lesson
objectives
review

Create a contact in ClaimCenter

Assign or reassign roles to contacts on a claim
Add a vendor contact to a claim

Describe how ClaimCenter and
ContactManager share contacts
